---
title: Advanced R - Chapter 2 Notes
freeze: true
format:
  html:
      toc: true
---

# 2 Names and Values
-   The distinction here allows prediction of when R will copy and object, with implications for performance and memory usage.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(lobstr)
```
:::


## 2.2 Binding Basics

The assignment operator `<-` creates a reference between names and objects.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Assigns a name to a value
x <- c(1, 2, 3)
```
:::


We have created an object and given it a name `x`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Assigns another name to the same object/value. Does not create a new value.
y <- x
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_addr(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "0x209008119f8"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_addr(y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "0x209008119f8"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
identical(obj_addr(x), obj_addr(y))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
a <- 1:10
b <- a
c <- b
d <- 1:10
```
:::


`a` is name of the value or object `1:10`. So are `b` and `c`. `d` is a name of an object different from the object with names `a`, `b`, and `c`.



## 2.3 Copy-on-modify

When does R make a copy?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(1, 2, 3)
y <- x

y[[3]] <- 4
x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> [1] 1 2 3
```
:::


Generally, R objects are immutable. So `x` wasn't changed when `y` was modified. A new object was created and bound to `y`. This is what is meant by **copy-on-modify**.

`tracemem()` tells you when an object is copied.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(1, 2, 3)
cat(tracemem(x), "\n")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
<0000020900791BD8> 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> <0x7f80c0e0ffc8> 
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
y <- x
y[[3]] <- 4L
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
tracemem[0x0000020900791bd8 -> 0x000002090079d408]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
```


:::
:::


Modifying `y` again does not produce a copy. The object is modified in place.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
y[[3]] <- 5L

untracemem(x)
```
:::


Function calls follow the same copying rules.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
f <- function(a) {
  a
}

x <- c(1, 2, 3)
cat(tracemem(x), "\n")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
<0000020900821408> 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> <0x557146b84928>

z <- f(x)
# there's no copy here!

untracemem(x)
```
:::


When the function `f()` is run, the argument `a` becomes a binding to the object already bound to `x`. The name `z` now points to the same object as `x`. The object is never copied because it is never modified.

Here is a list:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
l1 <- list(1, 2, 3)
```
:::


The list stores references to values. It does not store objects; it stores the names of objects.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
l2 <- l1
```
:::


Modifying a list creates a **shallow** copy. The list and its names are copied, but not the object the names point to.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
l2[[3]] <- 4
```
:::


You can see values shared across lists like so:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
lobstr::ref(l1, l2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
█ [1:0x20900833368] <list> 
├─[2:0x2090090be38] <dbl> 
├─[3:0x2090090bc78] <dbl> 
└─[4:0x2090090bab8] <dbl> 
 
█ [5:0x2090045c778] <list> 
├─[2:0x2090090be38] 
├─[3:0x2090090bc78] 
└─[6:0x208fd147dd0] <dbl> 
```


:::
:::



Data frames are lists of vectors.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
d1 <- data.frame(x = c(1, 5, 6), y = c(2, 4, 3))

d2 <- d1
d2[, 2] <- d2[, 2] * 2
```
:::


In this example, the object that is the first column is pointed to by both d1 and d2. Modifying a row means every column is modified, so each column must be "copied" and then edited.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
d3 <- d1
d3[1, ] <- d3[1, ] * 3
```
:::


R also uses references with character vectors (vectors of strings), which point to a global string pool.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c("a", "a", "abc", "d")
ref(x, character = TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
█ [1:0x2090095cea8] <chr> 
├─[2:0x208f4da70e0] <string: "a"> 
├─[2:0x208f4da70e0] 
├─[3:0x208fcc32a88] <string: "abc"> 
└─[4:0x208f93327e8] <string: "d"> 
```


:::
:::


Both of the first two names point to the same object.

### 2.3.6 Exercises


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(1L, 2L, 3L)
tracemem(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "<0000020900015988>"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
x[[3]] <- 4
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
tracemem[0x0000020900015988 -> 0x0000020900145f08]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020900145f08 -> 0x000002090057a228]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
a <- 1:10
b <- list(a, a)
c <- list(b, a, 1:10)

lobstr::ref(b,c)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
█ [1:0x209004258c8] <list> 
├─[2:0x208fd69eb30] <int> 
└─[2:0x208fd69eb30] 
 
█ [3:0x20900640dc8] <list> 
├─[1:0x209004258c8] 
├─[2:0x208fd69eb30] 
└─[4:0x208fd74f0b0] <int> 
```


:::
:::


## 2.4 Object size

How much memory does an object occupy? Use `lobstr::obj_size`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(letters)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
1.71 kB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(ggplot2::diamonds)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
3.46 MB
```


:::
:::



Lists are generally small since they are only references to values, not the values themselves.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- runif(1e6)
obj_size(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
8.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 8.00 MB

y <- list(x, x, x)
obj_size(y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
8.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 8.00 MB
```
:::


Thanks to the global string pool, character vectors take up less memory than you might expect. Also, the size of two objects combined is much easier to figure out if there are no shared values.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
banana <- "bananas bananas bananas"
obj_size(banana)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
136 B
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 136 B
obj_size(rep(banana, 100))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
928 B
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 928 B
```
:::



Alternative representation means sequences of numbers are all the same size. Only the first and last numbers are stored.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(1:5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
680 B
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(1:1e6)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
680 B
```


:::
:::



### 2.4.1 Exercises 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
y <- rep(list(runif(1e4)), 100)

object.size(y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
8005648 bytes
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 8005648 bytes
obj_size(y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
80.90 kB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 80.90 kB

# obj_size account for alternative representation of sequences.
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
funs <- list(mean, sd, var)
obj_size(funs)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
18.76 kB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> 18.76 kB

# The size is "somewhat misleading" because the size of lists refers to their names, not their objects?
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
a <- runif(1e6)
obj_size(a)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
8.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
b <- list(a, a)
obj_size(b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
8.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(a, b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
8.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
b[[1]][[1]] <- 10
obj_size(b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
16.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(a, b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
16.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
b[[2]][[1]] <- 10
obj_size(b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
16.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
obj_size(a, b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
24.00 MB
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# alt rep sequences are aking up 8 MB, and here we copy-on-modify twice, 
# creating three 8 MB sequences for a total of 24 MB by the last line of code.
```
:::



## 2.5 Modify-in-place

There are exceptions to copy-on-modify: single-named environments and objects. Objects with a single binding are performance optimized and environments are always modified in place.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
v <- c(1, 2, 3)
v[[3]] <- 4 # modified in place
```
:::





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- data.frame(matrix(runif(5 * 1e4), ncol = 5))
medians <- vapply(x, median, numeric(1))

for (i in seq_along(medians)) {
  x[[i]] <- x[[i]] - medians[[i]]
}
```
:::


A slow for loop. Slow because the dataframe is being copied 15 times - 3 times per iteration.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cat(tracemem(x), "\n")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
<0000020900679238> 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> <0x7f80c429e020> 

for (i in 1:5) {
  x[[i]] <- x[[i]] - medians[[i]]
}
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
tracemem[0x0000020900679238 -> 0x0000020904e74c78]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74c78 -> 0x0000020904e74c08]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74c08 -> 0x0000020904e74b98]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74b98 -> 0x0000020904e74b28]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74b28 -> 0x0000020904e74ab8]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74ab8 -> 0x0000020904e74a48]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74a48 -> 0x0000020904e749d8]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e749d8 -> 0x0000020904e74968]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e74968 -> 0x0000020904e748f8]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
tracemem[0x0000020904e748f8 -> 0x0000020904e74888]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> tracemem[0x7f80c429e020 -> 0x7f80c0c144d8]: 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c144d8 -> 0x7f80c0c14540]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14540 -> 0x7f80c0c145a8]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c145a8 -> 0x7f80c0c14610]: 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14610 -> 0x7f80c0c14678]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14678 -> 0x7f80c0c146e0]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c146e0 -> 0x7f80c0c14748]: 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14748 -> 0x7f80c0c147b0]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c147b0 -> 0x7f80c0c14818]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14818 -> 0x7f80c0c14880]: 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14880 -> 0x7f80c0c148e8]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c148e8 -> 0x7f80c0c14950]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14950 -> 0x7f80c0c149b8]: 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c149b8 -> 0x7f80c0c14a20]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 
#> tracemem[0x7f80c0c14a20 -> 0x7f80c0c14a88]: [[<-.data.frame [[<- 

untracemem(x)
```
:::


Using a list reduces the number of copies being made


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
y <- as.list(x)
cat(tracemem(y), "\n")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
<00000209056B8AF8> 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> <0x7f80c5c3de20>
  
for (i in 1:5) {
  y[[i]] <- y[[i]] - medians[[i]]
}
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
tracemem[0x00000209056b8af8 -> 0x000002090599a4d8]: eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main 
```


:::
:::


Environments are always modified in place. This is referred to as **reference semantics**. Modifying an environment does not change the existing bindings within an environment.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
e1 <- rlang::env(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3)
e2 <- e1
```
:::


Changing a binding means the environment is modified in place. That is, after `e1$c` is modified, e2$c now points to the same object.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
e1$c <- 4
e2$c
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 4
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> [1] 4
```
:::


Environments can contain themselves


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
e <- rlang::env()
e$self <- e

ref(e)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
█ [1:0x20903349b30] <env> 
└─self = [1:0x20903349b30] 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#> █ [1:0x557140f86b08] <env> 
#> └─self = [1:0x557140f86b08]
```
:::


### 2.5.3 Exercises


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- list()
x[[1]] <- x

# Doesn't create a circular list because x is modified in place due to single binding?
```
:::


## 2.6 Unbinding and the garbage collector

The garbage collector frees memory from objects without a referenced name.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- 1:3
x <- 2:4
rm(x)
```
:::


The objects that x was bound to still exist. Use the garbage collector to get rid of them. This actually runs automatically when you need more memory, so you never need to run it yourself.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
gc() # it does tell you the memory being used, which can be useful
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
          used (Mb) gc trigger  (Mb) max used  (Mb)
Ncells 1264174 67.6    2640178 141.1  2640178 141.1
Vcells 5825149 44.5   10146329  77.5  8258784  63.1
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mem_used()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
117.40 MB
```


:::
:::
